Simple solution for the neck gaiter or any similar-fitting mask/covering for the face:

Raise the fabric away from the edges of the mouth, so that much more of the fabric around the mouth and nose is being utilized. The findings, as you presented them, are only a part of the findings and if you don't know that, you have no business talking about research (the only other episode you got wrong also involved research so you may want to stay away from that area until you become competent in the subject matter). First, take this video down because it is dangerous and may end up killing someone in a couple weeks. Second, make a second video and explain the hows and whys this one was so very wrong - and present the correct findings and you could use it to show exactly how research is correctly used. This presentation is wholly wrong - in its approach and in its pronouncements. Research is NEVER done in isolation and the Duke U project was done in conjunction with two earlier studies. One published in June showed no benefit from bandana-type masks; a second published in July duplicated the findings of the first. This study looked at what possible mechanism explained the findings of the first two studies - which it did. The findings are that bandana-type masks offer no protection due to the aerosolizing effect they have been shown to have on exhaled droplets. This is why access to research should be restricted only to those qualified to discuss it competently. And, if I'm not mistaken, the first two research projects are cited in the Duke U one - which eliminates any possibility of claiming ignorance of their existence. I have used somewhere in the area of 100 of your shows as supplements for my students for good reason - they are trustworthy. You have presented yourself as a trustworthy source; as such there is also a liability involved as, if you present incorrect information, you can be held liable for damages because you present yourself as a reliable and trustworthy source of information. Do the right thing.

The blue flame does give the soot in the exact same quantity as the yellow flame. If you go in the kitchen and use a badly setup gas based stove then you will notice that all the soot from a blue flame ends up stacking on the outer layers of the cooking pans. If you are thinking about stopping the soot and gathering it in a fine powder then yea, the blue flame can do that. But I don't think it matters that much anyway because the quantities are tiny.
